G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody or visitation order may be modified "if the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child."

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: The Plaintiff, **Sarah Thompson** ("Mother"), brings this Complaint for Modification pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, seeking modification of an existing custody and parenting time order entered by the Barnstable Probate and Family Court on **April 15, 2019**.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 29 and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the original custody judgment was issued by this Court and both parties continue to have significant connections to the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 29.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 29 and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the original custody judgment was issued by this Court and both parties continue to have significant connections to the Commonwealth.

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Since the entry of the original order, **a substantial and material change in circumstances has occurred** within the meaning of *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010), and *Roe v. Roe*, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 967 (1990).
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a custodial parent to return to Massachusetts after a lawful relocation. It does not discuss, define, or apply the “substantial and material change in circumstances” standard, nor does it analyze modification of an existing custody or support order on that basis. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the asserted proposition that such a substantial and material change has occurred.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. … As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights. See G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), (b).”

*Roe v. Roe*, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 967 (199.proposition: Since the entry of the original order, **a substantial and material change in circumstances has occurred** within the meaning of *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010), and *Roe v. Roe*, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 967 (1990).
*Roe v. Roe*, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 967 (199.support_reasoning: Roe v. Roe is a paternity and child‑support case addressing retroactive support, equal protection, statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 209C, and the fairness of the support order. It does not concern modification of an existing order or the standard of “substantial and material change in circumstances” discussed in Smith v. McDonald. The opinion never articulates or applies any change‑of‑circumstances standard, so it cannot serve as authority for that proposition.
*Roe v. Roe*, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 967 (199.relevant_excerpt:
General Laws c. 209C, § 9(a), read in conjunction with G. L. c. 209C, § 1, authorizes orders in cases of illegitimacy for current support of a child, for retroactive support from the date of birth, and for provision of health insurance.
...
Nor do we agree that there is any other basis for setting aside the financial order.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The material change in circumstances — specifically, Father’s relocation and the resulting disruption to Emily’s rest, schooling, and overall wellbeing — has rendered the current parenting schedule no longer in Emily’s best interests under *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), and *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Rosenthal concerns when a prior custody order may be modified and holds that a change in custody must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the custodial parent’s relocation. The court finds no such post‑divorce change sufficient to justify transferring custody and emphasizes that the prior custodial arrangement had caused no ill effects. It does not address a situation where a noncustodial parent’s relocation and resulting disruption to a child’s rest, schooling, or wellbeing make an existing parenting schedule no longer in the child’s best interests, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which… had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995.”

*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.proposition: The material change in circumstances — specifically, Father’s relocation and the resulting disruption to Emily’s rest, schooling, and overall wellbeing — has rendered the current parenting schedule no longer in Emily’s best interests under *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), and *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.support_reasoning: Williams v. Massa concerns original divorce, property division, alimony/support, and the form of a future custody-modification mechanism. It does not involve a postjudgment relocation by a parent, does not analyze what constitutes a ‘material change in circumstances,’ and does not apply a best-interests analysis to modify an existing parenting schedule based on changed facts. The only custody-related holding is that any future change in custody must proceed by complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, not by motion, so it does not support the specific proposition about relocation-driven material change and Emily’s best interests under Rosenthal v. Maney.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the **best interests of the child** remain the paramount consideration.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal/custody matters, the best interests of the children remain the paramount concern. The court interprets the Massachusetts removal statute as requiring that removal be in the best interests of the child and frames its entire analysis around determining those interests, thereby affirming that this is the controlling consideration under Massachusetts law.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the **best interests of the child** remain the paramount consideration.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that under G.L. c. 208, § 30, removal may be ordered only if it is in the children’s best interests, and repeatedly frames the analysis around whether removal serves the children’s best interests. It further notes that the best-interests standard is grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the child, confirming that the child’s best interests are the paramount consideration in this context of Massachusetts family law.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that … [a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ … ‘The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’”

*Signorelli v. Albano*, 21 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A substantial geographic relocation of a parent, when it significantly affects a child’s stability, school attendance, or wellbeing, constitutes a material change warranting review.
*Signorelli v. Albano*, 21 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The case concerns removal of a child from the jurisdiction by a custodial parent, but it does not hold that a substantial relocation, by itself or due to effects on stability, school, or wellbeing, constitutes a “material change” warranting modification or review. Instead, the Appeals Court vacates and remands because the trial judge failed to apply the Yannas “real advantage” standard and instructs that all interests and visitation alternatives be weighed collectively. The opinion is about the proper substantive standard for removal, not about defining a relocation as a material change triggering review.
*Signorelli v. Albano*, 21 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… the court adopted a standard, sometimes called the ‘real advantage’ standard… ‘the first consideration’ in determining whether the child’s best interests are served, ‘is whether there is a good reason for the move, a “real advantage.”’… Under Yannas… once such a real advantage has been shown, ‘none of the relevant factors becomes controlling in deciding the best interests of the child, but rather they must be considered collectively. Every person, parent and child, has an interest to be considered.’”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: A substantial geographic relocation of a parent, when it significantly affects a child’s stability, school attendance, or wellbeing, constitutes a material change warranting review.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses removal standards and child support modification, not whether a substantial geographic relocation itself constitutes a material change warranting review. The case involves a custodial parent’s request to relocate out of state and applies the Yannas ‘real advantage/best interests’ framework under G.L. c. 208, § 30, rather than treating relocation’s effect on stability, schooling, or wellbeing as a material change justifying reopening custody or parenting orders. Thus, it does not establish the proposition stated.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas… ‘[T]he first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’ … Second, if the real advantage test is satisfied, the judge must consider whether the move is in the best interests of the children.’”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The Court also has continuing jurisdiction to amend custody and parenting time to serve the child’s best interests.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standards for determining custody and visitation at the time of the divorce judgment (best interests of the child, parental equality, etc.), but it does not address the Probate and Family Court’s *continuing* jurisdiction to later amend or modify custody or parenting time orders. There is no discussion of post-judgment modification, retained jurisdiction, or statutory authority for ongoing power to amend orders. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the proposition about continuing jurisdiction.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.” (Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402-403 (1981).) [Note: the opinion otherwise contains no discussion of continuing jurisdiction or modification of custody/visitation orders.]

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Court also has continuing jurisdiction to amend custody and parenting time to serve the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best-interests standard for making an initial custody and parenting-time award and affirms the trial judge’s custody order and parenting schedule. It does not address the Probate and Family Court’s *continuing* jurisdiction to later amend or modify custody or parenting time. There is no language about post-judgment modification authority, so this case does not support the proposition that the court has ongoing jurisdiction to amend custody and parenting time to serve the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child” ….’ … The judge has discretion when awarding custody of a child to which we give ‘substantial deference.’ … Moreover, the judge stated that, should Rose decide to move back to Massachusetts, the parties must work in good faith to adjust their parenting plan to meet Jill’s best interests.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The modification requested herein seeks to ensure Emily’s health, education, and welfare remain protected, consistent with *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003) and *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition is a general, purposive statement that the requested modification is to protect the child’s health, education, and welfare. Custody of Kali reaffirms that custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) must be made based on the child’s best interests, with particular attention to which parent is more attuned to the child’s medical, educational, and daily needs and can better provide for the child’s welfare. While the case does not speak specifically about modifications, it clearly supports the broader principle that custody arrangements should protect the child’s health, education, and welfare.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: The judge’s custody award was based on his conclusion that these arrangements were in the best interests of the child. This conclusion was based, in turn, on a number of findings, including, inter alia, that the mother provides well for Kali’s physical needs, is concerned with her health and educational issues, and is the one who “preoccupies herself” with Kali’s care regarding clothing, hygiene, doctor’s appointments, and child care providers; … and is better able to provide for Kali’s welfare and physical needs during the week.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The modification requested herein seeks to ensure Emily’s health, education, and welfare remain protected, consistent with *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003) and *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Custody of Vaughn for the broad idea that a custody modification should protect a child’s health, education, and welfare. Vaughn, however, is focused on requiring explicit findings about the impact of domestic violence on the child and the appropriateness of custody in light of that violence, not on the general best‑interests formulation or on modifications per se. While the opinion certainly relates to protecting a child’s welfare, it does not articulate the specific, generic best‑interests language the proposition suggests, so the citation is somewhat overstated for that purpose.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Courts have repeatedly recognized that disruption to a child’s schooling and rest patterns is contrary to the child’s best interests.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses best interests of the child in the context of custody, visitation, abuse, and removal, but it does not address disruption to a child’s schooling or rest patterns, nor does it articulate any general principle about such disruption being contrary to a child’s best interests. The only mention of stability is in the context of residential stability and general ‘status quo,’ not school or sleep schedules. Therefore this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In determining the best interests of the child, weight, of course, should be given to the fact that ‘[stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003).”
